column3: ...why?\nI think it makes sense to be able to support different proxy types.\n

SOCKS5 exists since 1996, so SOCKS4 is even older... I remember @sipa expressed he would like to get rid of it some time ago, so I decided to do it. Also most current SOCKS servers should handle SOCKS5 just fine (+ it allows a much cleaner proxy setup in our code).\n
True - I can't think of anything that still uses SOCKS4. SOCKS5 is also safer as it allows DNS lookups over the proxy.\n
I've posted a question regarding SOCKS4 usage on the development mailing list. If no one responds I take that as no one cares and we can go ahead.\n
@laanwj Should I add a deprecation warning like we have for `-debugnet` and soon `-tor`?\n

I haven't had any replies to my post, so I assume it's not very important. No one is crying that SOCKS4 is going to go.

Anyhow, how is the error handling? it should at least fail with an error if the user still specifies a SOCKS4 proxy, instead of silently doing anything nefarious like bypass the proxy.
Right, that was my question... I'll add a check to catch SOCKS4.\n
Added commit to error out, when -socks is detected.\n
Not sure why this fails, can't find the error. @laanwj Can you take a look at the log: http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/p4327_e6887911c08dae8d4e606d9c4ec5f03a1976cf3b/test.log\n
Random pulltester failure if you ask me...\n

Automatic sanity-testing: PASSED, see http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/p4327_a339a37b28176135c7fe5adbd3b50da77a45373d/ for binaries and test log.\nThis test script verifies pulls every time they are updated. It, however, dies sometimes and fails to test properly.  If you are waiting on a test, please check timestamps to verify that the test.log is moving at http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-te

After this we can assume that any proxy (if set) can accept domain names, so we can get rid of the separate NameProxy and just use whatever proxy is set for IPv4/IPv6. Not necessary in this pull of course.\n

This message is not correct:
- SOCKS4 is not deprecated, that would imply it is still there but will go away later, support is removed completely by this pull
- SOCKS5 was always the default, but it is now the only option

It reads -socks argument is deprecated and we don't have SOCKS4 support anymore. I agree the SOCKS5 sentence can be removed.

What about `Error: Deprecated argument -socks found. Setting SOCKS version isn't possible anymore, only SOCKS5 is supported.`
But deprecation is never an error, just a warning. It means to warn that something will go away in the future. It doesn't fit in this sentence.\n
Then it also doesn't fit for -debugnet, nor -tor... will rephrase.\n
